rNRBCx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
nests dug in soft soil in open areas usually within 100 yards of water (USFWS 1981, in NatureServe 2005). Since will nest along edge, select all pixels in hydro buffer IN ADDITION TO those selected MUs. Do not restrict selected MUs to hydro buffer. Amy Silvano.Amy Silvano 8jul05

I added map units for this species including marshes, lake/pondshore, and floodplain/riparian habitats. I also included a 2000m interior hydro buffer to exclude center of bays/sounds that were being selected because of the 0m interior buffer and water selection as a PMU in previous model iteration. There IS NO NEED TO RUN A HAND MODEL. I removed the hand modeling. MJR 9 November 2007.

rNRBCx-y3.memHandModelNotes:
nests dug in soft soil in open areas usually within 100 yards of water (USFWS 1981, in NatureServe 2005). Since will nest along edge, select all pixels in hydro buffer IN ADDITION TO those selected MUs. Do not restrict selected MUs to hydro buffer. Amy Silvano.Amy Silvano 8jul05

I added map units for this species including marshes, lake/pondshore, and floodplain/riparian habitats. I also included a 2000m interior hydro buffer to exclude center of bays/sounds that were being selected because of the 0m interior buffer and water selection as a PMU in previous model iteration. There IS NO NEED TO RUN A HAND MODEL. I removed the hand modeling. MJR 9 November 2007.

references: DeGraaf, R. M., and D. D. Rudis. 1983. Amphibians and reptiles of New England. Habitats and natural history. Univ. Massachusetts Press. vii + 83 pp.
Browne, R. A., N. A. Haskell, C. R. Griffin, and J. W. Ridgeway. 1996. Genetic variation among populations of the redbelly turtle (PSEUDEMYS RUBRIVENTRIS). Copeia 1996:192-195.
Seidel, M. E., and W. M. Palmer. 1991. Morphological variation in turtles of the genus PSEUDEMYS (Testudines:Emydidae) from central Atlantic drainages. Brimleyana 17:105-135.
Ernst, C. H., and R. W. Barbour. 1972. Turtles of the United States. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 347 pp.
Seidel, M. E. 1994. Morphometric analysis and taxonomy of cooter and red-bellied turtles in the North American genus PSEUDEMYS (Emydidae). Chelonian Conservation and Biology 1(2):117-130.
Iverson, J. B., and T. E. Graham. 1990. Geographic variation in the redbelly turtle, PSEUDEMYS RUBRIVENTRIS (Reptilia:Testudines). Ann. Carnegie Mus. 59:1-13.
U.S. Dept. of the Interior. 1981. Plymouth red-bellied turtle recovery plan. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Region 5, 13 pp.
U. S. Fish & Wildlife Service. 1981. Plymouth red-bellied turtle recovery plan.
Carr, A. 1952. Handbook of Turtles. Cornell University Press, Ithaca, NY. 542 pp.
Graham, T. E. 1991. PSEUDEMYS RUBRIVENTRIS. Cat. Am. Amph. Rept. 510.1-510.4.
Mitchell, J. C. 1994. The reptiles of Virginia. Washington, DC: Smithsonian Institution Press.
habitat_description:
The range for the red-bellied cooter includes Mid-Atlantic Coastal Plain from central New Jersey to North Carolina; westward in Potomac River to eastern West Virginia, separated populations in Plymouth County, southeastern Massachusetts; questionable record from Naushon Island, Massachusetts introduced and possibly established in New York (Graham 1991).

Habitats include relatively large deep bodies of water: creeks, rivers, marshes, ponds, lakes, sometimes in brackish water while Massachusetts population in ponds only (USFWS 1981). Soft bottom and abundant aquatic vegetation preferred and wanders on land in fall and spring. Eggs are laid usually within 100 yards in nests dug in soft soil in open areas (USFWS 1981).  Nests often in tilled or disturbed soil (DeGraaf and Rudis 1983; Ernst and Barbour 1972).
